options.D: Only wire requires drying, not flux

explanations.A: Moisture-contaminated flux introduces hydrogen causing cracking; proper handling is essential.
explanations.B: SAW flux absorbs moisture from air; low-hydrogen applications require flux baking (typically 250-450°C for 1-2 hours) to remove moisture and storage in heated hoppers to maintain dryness preventing hydrogen cracking.
explanations.C: Moisture introduces hydrogen which promotes cracking in restrained joints on high-strength or crack-sensitive steels.
explanations.D: Both flux and wire can absorb moisture; flux is the primary concern since it constitutes most of the shielding system.

questions.taskTitle: Welds using submerged arc welding (SAW) process
questions.subtask: D-15.01 Selects SAW equipment and consumables
questions.question: What type of power source is typically used for SAW applications?

options.A: Constant current (CC) only
options.B: Constant voltage (CV) with DC or AC capability
options.C: Battery-powered portable units
options.D: Solar-powered equipment

explanations.A: CC is used for SMAW and GTAW; SAW typically uses CV for stable wire feeding.
explanations.B: SAW uses constant voltage power sources (like GMAW) to maintain stable arc length with continuous wire feed; both DC and AC capability are common, with AC often used for reducing arc blow on heavy sections.
explanations.C: SAW's high power requirements make battery operation impractical; line power is required.
explanations.D: Solar power is insufficient for SAW's high power demands (often 40-60 kW or more).

questions.taskTitle: Welds using submerged arc welding (SAW) process
questions.subtask: D-15.01 Selects SAW equipment and consumables
questions.question: For SAW with multiple electrode wires (tandem or multi-wire), what is the primary benefit?

options.A: Reduced equipment cost
options.B: Ability to weld in vertical position
options.C: Dramatically increased deposition rates and productivity
options.D: Elimination of flux requirements

explanations.A: Multiple wire systems increase equipment complexity and cost, not reduce it.
explanations.B: Position capability remains flat/horizontal regardless of number of electrodes; gravity still limits position.
explanations.C: Tandem or multi-wire SAW (2-5 wires) dramatically increases deposition rates (potentially exceeding 100 kg/hr), ideal for high-volume production of heavy fabrications like shipbuilding or pressure vessel manufacturing.
explanations.D: All SAW configurations require flux regardless of number of electrodes.

questions.taskTitle: Welds using submerged arc welding (SAW) process
questions.subtask: D-15.02 Sets up SAW equipment
questions.question: What is the typical electrode extension (stickout) for SAW welding?

explanations.A: 3-6 mm is far too short for SAW; this is typical for GTAW, not SAW.
explanations.B: 13-16 mm is still too short; SAW uses longer stickout for resistive preheating benefits.
explanations.C: SAW typically uses 25-38 mm electrode extension, allowing resistive preheating of the wire (increasing deposition efficiency) while maintaining adequate contact tip life and arc stability under the flux blanket.
explanations.D: 50-75 mm is excessive even for SAW and would cause wire feeding instability and arc control problems.

questions.taskTitle: Welds using submerged arc welding (SAW) process
questions.subtask: D-15.02 Sets up SAW equipment
questions.question: When setting up SAW equipment, what flux depth over the weld area is typically required?

options.A: Light dusting barely covering the wire
options.B: 25-40 mm (1-1.5 in.) covering the arc completely
options.C: 75-100 mm (3-4 in.) thick blanket
options.D: Flux depth is not important

explanations.A: Light dusting provides inadequate arc coverage resulting in spatter, porosity, and poor shielding.
explanations.B: SAW requires 25-40 mm flux depth to completely submerge the arc, providing proper shielding, insulation for heat concentration, and protection from atmospheric contamination while allowing flux recycling.
explanations.C: 75-100 mm is excessive waste of flux without additional benefit; 25-40 mm is adequate.
explanations.D: Proper flux depth is critical for shielding quality, arc stability, and overall weld quality in SAW.

questions.taskTitle: Welds using submerged arc welding (SAW) process
questions.subtask: D-15.02 Sets up SAW equipment
questions.question: For SAW setup, what is the purpose of the flux recovery system?

options.A: To heat the flux before welding
options.B: To vacuum unfused flux for cleaning and reuse, reducing costs
options.C: To mix different flux types together
options.D: To add moisture to the flux

explanations.A: Flux recovery systems collect unused flux; heating is done separately if required.
explanations.B: Flux recovery systems vacuum unfused flux from around the weld after completion, clean it, and return it to the hopper for reuse; typically 50-80% of flux is recoverable, significantly reducing consumable costs.
explanations.C: Different flux types should not be mixed; recovery systems maintain flux identity.
explanations.D: Recovery systems should maintain flux dryness, not add moisture which would cause hydrogen problems.

questions.taskTitle: Welds using submerged arc welding (SAW) process
questions.subtask: D-15.02 Sets up SAW equipment
questions.question: When setting up SAW travel mechanisms, what angle is typically used for the electrode holder relative to the workpiece?

options.A: Perpendicular (90°) to the work surface
options.B: Trailing angle of 5-15° from perpendicular
options.C: Leading angle of 45° from perpendicular
options.D: Angle has no effect on SAW welding

explanations.A: While perpendicular can work, slight trailing angle is often preferred for bead shape and penetration.
explanations.B: SAW electrodes typically use trailing angle of 5-15° from perpendicular (tilted opposite to travel direction), promoting good bead shape, penetration profile, and slag removal characteristics.
explanations.C: 45° leading angle is excessive and would negatively affect penetration and bead formation.
explanations.D: Electrode angle affects arc force direction, penetration pattern, and bead geometry in SAW.

questions.taskTitle: Welds using submerged arc welding (SAW) process
questions.subtask: D-15.02 Sets up SAW equipment
questions.question: For SAW on heavy plate experiencing arc blow, what setup modification can help?

options.A: Switch from DC to AC welding current
options.B: Increase travel speed dramatically
options.C: Remove all flux from the area
options.D: Use smaller diameter electrode wire

explanations.A: AC welding current eliminates magnetic arc blow problems because the alternating current prevents magnetic field buildup that causes arc deflection, particularly useful on heavy sections or when welding near plate edges.
explanations.B: Travel speed changes don't address the magnetic forces causing arc blow.
explanations.C: Removing flux would eliminate the SAW shielding system; arc blow requires different solutions.
explanations.D: Wire diameter doesn't significantly affect arc blow; current type (AC vs DC) is the effective control.

questions.taskTitle: Welds using submerged arc welding (SAW) process
questions.subtask: D-15.02 Sets up SAW equipment
questions.question: When setting up SAW equipment for circumferential welds on pipe, what additional equipment is typically required?

options.A: Vertical welding attachment
options.B: Turning rolls or rotator to rotate the pipe while welding head remains stationary
options.C: Magnetic arc control device
options.D: No special equipment needed

explanations.A: Vertical welding is not typically done with SAW due to flux containment issues.
explanations.B: Pipe circumferential SAW requires turning rolls or rotators to rotate the pipe in the horizontal plane, maintaining the weld in flat position while the SAW head remains stationary, optimizing SAW's position limitations.
explanations.C: While arc control may be used, rotation equipment is the fundamental requirement for pipe SAW.
explanations.D: Pipe rotation equipment is essential for effective SAW on circumferential pipe welds.

questions.taskTitle: Welds using submerged arc welding (SAW) process
questions.subtask: D-15.02 Sets up SAW equipment
questions.question: For SAW setup, what is the function of the flux hopper?

options.A: To melt the flux before welding
options.B: To store and feed flux ahead of the welding electrode
options.C: To remove slag after welding
options.D: To cool the weld area

explanations.A: Flux is not melted before welding; it melts in the arc heat during welding.
explanations.B: The flux hopper stores granular flux and continuously feeds it ahead of and around the electrode during welding, maintaining proper flux blanket depth to submerge the arc completely.
explanations.C: Fused slag removal is done after welding; recovery systems collect unfused flux, not slag.
explanations.D: While flux blanket does insulate heat, the hopper's function is flux storage and delivery, not cooling.

questions.taskTitle: Welds using submerged arc welding (SAW) process
questions.subtask: D-15.02 Sets up SAW equipment
questions.question: When setting up wire feed for SAW, what drive roll configuration is typically used?

options.A: Single drive roll only
options.B: V-groove drive rolls with firm pressure
options.C: U-groove drive rolls for soft aluminum
options.D: Wire feed isn't used in SAW

explanations.A: Single roll provides insufficient grip for consistent feeding; paired rolls are required.
explanations.B: SAW uses V-groove drive rolls (similar to FCAW) with firm pressure to positively feed solid steel wire at high rates, ensuring consistent wire delivery for stable arc and deposition.
explanations.C: U-groove rolls are for soft aluminum wire; SAW typically uses steel wire requiring V-groove positive grip.
explanations.D: SAW requires continuous wire feed systems similar to GMAW/FCAW for automated operation.

questions.taskTitle: Welds using submerged arc welding (SAW) process
questions.subtask: D-15.03 Sets operating parameters for SAW
questions.question: For SAW on carbon steel plate, what current range is typical for single-wire operation with 4.0 mm (5/32 in.) electrode?

explanations.A: 100-200 amps is far too low for SAW with 4.0 mm wire; this is more typical of GTAW or light GMAW.
explanations.B: 300-400 amps is still low for SAW; higher currents are used to achieve high deposition rates.
explanations.C: SAW with 4.0 mm electrode typically operates at 600-900 amps for single-wire applications, providing high deposition rates (10-20 kg/hr) and deep penetration characteristic of the process.
explanations.D: 1200-1500 amps would require multiple wires or special applications; single wire at 4.0 mm typically peaks around 1000 amps.

questions.taskTitle: Welds using submerged arc welding (SAW) process
questions.subtask: D-15.03 Sets operating parameters for SAW
questions.question: When welding thick plate with SAW, how does increasing travel speed affect the weld bead?

options.A: Increases both penetration and width
options.B: Decreases penetration, creates narrower, more convex bead
options.C: Has no effect on bead geometry
options.D: Eliminates need for flux

explanations.A: Increased travel speed reduces heat input per unit length, decreasing rather than increasing penetration.
explanations.B: Increasing SAW travel speed reduces heat input per unit length, decreasing penetration depth while creating narrower, more convex bead profile; this relationship helps control penetration and bead shape.
explanations.C: Travel speed significantly affects heat input distribution and resulting bead geometry.
explanations.D: Travel speed is a parameter adjustment; flux requirements don't change with speed variations.

questions.taskTitle: Welds using submerged arc welding (SAW) process
questions.subtask: D-15.03 Sets operating parameters for SAW
questions.question: For SAW welding, what voltage range is typical for controlling arc length and bead width?

options.A: 10-15 volts
options.B: 20-25 volts
options.C: 28-36 volts
options.D: 45-60 volts

explanations.A: 10-15 volts is too low for SAW; arc would be unstable or extinguished.
explanations.B: 20-25 volts is borderline low; SAW typically operates at higher voltages than GMAW short circuit.
explanations.C: SAW typically operates at 28-36 volts; higher voltages within this range produce wider, flatter beads with less penetration, while lower voltages create narrower beads with deeper penetration.
explanations.D: 45-60 volts is excessive for most SAW applications and would cause very wide, uncontrolled beads.

questions.taskTitle: Welds using submerged arc welding (SAW) process
questions.subtask: D-15.03 Sets operating parameters for SAW
questions.question: When setting SAW parameters for fillet welds, what leg size can typically be achieved in a single pass?

options.A: Maximum 3 mm (1/8 in.)
options.B: Up to 6 mm (1/4 in.)
options.D: No limit on single-pass fillet size

explanations.A: 3 mm is far too small; SAW's high deposition capability allows much larger single-pass fillets.
explanations.B: 6 mm underestimates SAW capability; larger fillets are routinely made in single pass.
explanations.C: SAW's high deposition rates allow single-pass fillet welds up to approximately 8-12 mm leg size (depending on joint configuration and parameters), significantly improving productivity over multi-pass techniques.
explanations.D: While SAW has high capability, practical limits exist based on heat input, solidification, and slag control.

questions.taskTitle: Welds using submerged arc welding (SAW) process
questions.subtask: D-15.03 Sets operating parameters for SAW
questions.question: For SAW on carbon steel, what polarity is most commonly used?

options.A: DC electrode negative (DCEN)
options.B: DC electrode positive (DCEP)
options.C: AC only
options.D: Polarity is not applicable to SAW

explanations.A: DCEN provides less penetration and is rarely used for SAW on steel.
explanations.B: DCEP (electrode positive) is standard for SAW on carbon steel, providing good penetration, stable arc, and appropriate heat balance between electrode and workpiece for most applications.
explanations.C: While AC is used (especially for arc blow control), DCEP is more common for standard applications.
explanations.D: Polarity significantly affects SAW welding characteristics and penetration profile.

questions.taskTitle: Welds using submerged arc welding (SAW) process
questions.subtask: D-15.03 Sets operating parameters for SAW
questions.question: When increasing current in SAW while maintaining voltage, what primary effect occurs?

options.A: Decreased penetration and wider bead
options.B: Increased penetration depth and deposition rate
options.C: No change in weld characteristics
options.D: Elimination of flux consumption

explanations.A: Increasing current increases penetration rather than decreasing it; width is primarily affected by voltage.
explanations.B: Increasing SAW current (while holding voltage constant) increases both penetration depth and metal deposition rate, as higher current provides more heat input and melts more electrode wire per unit time.
explanations.C: Current is a primary parameter significantly affecting penetration, deposition, and bead profile.
explanations.D: Higher current increases flux consumption due to greater arc energy; flux usage doesn't cease.

questions.taskTitle: Welds using submerged arc welding (SAW) process
questions.subtask: D-15.03 Sets operating parameters for SAW
questions.question: For SAW narrow-gap welding applications, what parameter adjustment is typically made?

options.A: Very high voltage for wide beads
options.B: Lower voltage with oscillation for adequate sidewall fusion
options.C: Maximum travel speed possible
options.D: Eliminate flux entirely

explanations.A: High voltage creates wide beads inappropriate for narrow gaps; controlled voltage with oscillation is required.
explanations.B: Narrow-gap SAW uses lower voltage (producing narrower beads) combined with mechanical oscillation of the electrode to ensure adequate sidewall fusion in the narrow groove, maximizing deposition efficiency in thick sections.
explanations.C: Travel speed is typically slower in narrow gap to ensure complete fusion; this isn't maximized.
explanations.D: Flux is still essential in narrow-gap SAW for shielding; special feed arrangements accommodate the narrow groove.

questions.taskTitle: Welds using submerged arc welding (SAW) process
questions.subtask: D-15.03 Sets operating parameters for SAW
questions.question: When using tandem-wire SAW, what is the typical current relationship between leading and trailing electrodes?

options.A: Both electrodes at identical current
options.B: Leading electrode at higher current for penetration, trailing at lower current for fill
options.C: Leading at lower current, trailing at higher current
options.D: Current relationship doesn't matter

explanations.A: While equal currents can be used, typically leading wire uses higher current for specific reasons.
explanations.B: Tandem SAW typically uses higher current on leading electrode to establish penetration and weld pool, while trailing electrode at somewhat lower current fills the joint, optimizing both penetration and deposition rate.
explanations.C: Reversed relationship (low leading, high trailing) is atypical and would not optimize penetration/fill balance.
explanations.D: Current balance between electrodes significantly affects penetration, bead shape, and overall quality.

questions.taskTitle: Welds using submerged arc welding (SAW) process
questions.subtask: D-15.04 Performs weld using SAW equipment
questions.question: When performing SAW, what is the correct procedure for starting the weld?

options.A: Strike arc on the workpiece, then add flux
options.B: Position flux blanket first, then lower electrode to strike arc beneath flux
options.C: Start without any flux coverage
options.D: Touch electrode to work continuously before starting

explanations.A: Starting arc without flux causes spatter and poor shielding; flux must be in place first.
explanations.B: SAW starting procedure: deposit flux blanket over start area, lower electrode through flux to work, then energize to strike arc beneath flux layer, ensuring proper shielding from the first moment.
explanations.C: Starting without flux defeats the fundamental SAW shielding principle causing spatter and oxidation.
explanations.D: Continuous touching creates erratic starting and potential electrode stubbing; controlled start under flux is required.

questions.taskTitle: Welds using submerged arc welding (SAW) process
questions.subtask: D-15.04 Performs weld using SAW equipment
questions.question: For SAW welding, how is the slag removed after welding?

options.A: Slag self-removes during welding
options.B: Wire brush while weld is still molten
options.C: Allow cooling then chip off as continuous layer (often self-peeling)
options.D: Grind completely flush with power tools

explanations.A: SAW slag solidifies on the weld and requires removal; it doesn't self-remove during welding.
explanations.B: Brushing molten weld is dangerous and impossible; slag removal occurs after cooling.
explanations.C: SAW produces heavy slag layer that, after cooling, is typically chipped or often self-peels off in large sections due to differential contraction, revealing smooth weld bead beneath; minimal cleanup is often required.
explanations.D: Grinding is rarely necessary; SAW slag usually removes cleanly without power tool intervention.

questions.taskTitle: Welds using submerged arc welding (SAW) process
questions.subtask: D-15.04 Performs weld using SAW equipment
questions.question: When performing SAW on thick plate with backing strip, what observation during welding indicates proper penetration?

options.A: No visible indication during welding (process is completely submerged)
options.B: Bright flash every few seconds
options.C: Continuous crackling sound
options.D: Large amount of visible smoke

explanations.A: SAW arc is completely submerged beneath flux; welders cannot directly observe the arc during welding and must rely on pre-set parameters, monitoring equipment, and post-weld inspection to verify penetration and quality.
explanations.B: Visible flashing indicates inadequate flux coverage or arc exposure—a problem requiring correction.
explanations.C: While some sound occurs, SAW is relatively quiet compared to other processes due to flux insulation.
explanations.D: Visible smoke suggests flux burning or inadequate coverage; properly shielded SAW produces minimal visible emissions.

questions.taskTitle: Welds using submerged arc welding (SAW) process
questions.subtask: D-15.04 Performs weld using SAW equipment
questions.question: For SAW longitudinal seam welding on pipe or vessels, what equipment arrangement is most efficient?

options.A: Hand-held SAW torch (manual operation)
options.B: Fixed workpiece with traveling SAW head on track
options.C: Rotating workpiece with stationary SAW head position
options.D: SAW cannot be used for longitudinal seams

explanations.A: SAW is not practical for hand-held operation due to flux containment and equipment weight.
explanations.B: Longitudinal SAW seams use traveling SAW head (on carriage or track) moving along the fixed workpiece, maintaining consistent parameters and straight travel for optimal quality and productivity.
explanations.C: Rotating workpiece is used for circumferential welds; longitudinal seams require travel along the seam length.
explanations.D: SAW is excellent for longitudinal seams; proper equipment setup makes this highly productive.

questions.taskTitle: Welds using submerged arc welding (SAW) process
questions.subtask: D-15.04 Performs weld using SAW equipment
questions.question: When performing multi-pass SAW welding, what is the recommended approach for inter-pass cleaning?

options.A: No cleaning required between SAW passes
options.B: Remove slag from previous pass before depositing next pass
options.C: Grind each pass to bare metal
options.D: Apply additional flux only without slag removal

explanations.A: Slag must be removed to prevent slag inclusions in subsequent passes.
explanations.B: Between SAW passes, previous slag must be completely removed (typically by chipping as it often self-peels) to prevent slag entrapment, ensuring proper fusion between passes.
explanations.C: Complete grinding is excessive; slag removal by chipping or peeling is usually adequate for SAW.
explanations.D: Welding over unremoved slag causes slag inclusion defects in the new weld layer.

questions.taskTitle: Welds using submerged arc welding (SAW) process
questions.subtask: D-15.04 Performs weld using SAW equipment
questions.question: For SAW on carbon steel, what weld bead appearance indicates proper parameter selection?

options.A: Rough, irregular surface with trapped flux
options.B: Smooth, uniform bead with consistent width and slag coverage
options.C: Excessive undercut at both toes
options.D: Heavily oxidized black surface

explanations.A: Rough, irregular surface indicates parameter problems or improper flux depth.
explanations.B: Properly executed SAW produces smooth, uniform bead with consistent width, proper reinforcement, and complete slag coverage that removes cleanly, indicating correct current, voltage, and travel speed balance.
explanations.C: Undercut indicates excessive voltage or improper travel speed requiring parameter adjustment.
explanations.D: Heavy oxidation suggests inadequate flux coverage or shielding problems requiring investigation.

questions.taskTitle: Welds using submerged arc welding (SAW) process
questions.subtask: D-15.04 Performs weld using SAW equipment
questions.question: When performing SAW and porosity is discovered in the weld, what is the most likely cause?

options.A: Excessive welding current
options.B: Contaminated base metal or damp flux
options.C: Travel speed too slow
options.D: Electrode diameter too large

explanations.A: While high current affects bead shape, porosity typically results from contamination, not current level.
explanations.B: SAW porosity most commonly results from contaminated base metal (oil, paint, rust, moisture) or moisture in the flux introducing hydrogen or other gases that become trapped in solidifying weld metal.
explanations.C: Travel speed affects bead shape and heat input but is not the primary porosity cause.
explanations.D: Electrode diameter affects deposition rate but not directly porosity formation.

questions.taskTitle: Welds using submerged arc welding (SAW) process
questions.subtask: D-15.04 Performs weld using SAW equipment
questions.question: For SAW termination (run-off), what technique prevents crater cracking?

options.A: Abruptly stop welding at the end of joint
options.B: Continue welding onto run-off tabs or gradually reduce current while continuing travel
options.C: Increase travel speed dramatically at the end
options.D: Remove all flux before stopping

explanations.A: Abrupt termination creates crater with stress concentration prone to cracking.
explanations.B: Proper SAW termination uses run-off tabs to continue weld beyond the joint, or employs current taper-down while maintaining travel, filling the crater and preventing the rapid cooling and stress concentration that causes crater cracking.
explanations.C: Rapid speed increase creates crater without proper fill, promoting cracking.
explanations.D: Flux removal before stopping exposes arc causing spatter and doesn't address crater issues.

questions.taskTitle: Welds using submerged arc welding (SAW) process
questions.subtask: D-15.04 Performs weld using SAW equipment
questions.question: When using SAW for T-joint fillet welds, what position provides optimal productivity?

options.A: Vertical position
options.B: Overhead position
options.C: Horizontal position with joint in flat orientation
options.D: Any position works equally well

explanations.A: Vertical position is impractical for SAW; flux cannot be contained against gravity.
explanations.B: Overhead position is impossible for SAW; flux would fall away from the joint.
explanations.C: SAW T-joints are positioned horizontally so the fillet weld is in flat position, allowing flux blanket retention and taking full advantage of SAW's high deposition rate capability for productive single-pass fillets.
explanations.D: SAW is limited to flat and horizontal positions due to flux retention requirements.

questions.taskTitle: Welds using submerged arc welding (SAW) process
questions.subtask: D-15.04 Performs weld using SAW equipment
questions.question: For SAW edge preparation on thick plate, what groove angle is typical for single-sided welding?

options.A: 0° (square groove) regardless of thickness
options.B: 30-45° included angle
options.C: 60-70° included angle
options.D: 90° or greater included angle

explanations.A: Square grooves are only suitable for very thin sections; thick plate requires beveling for penetration.
explanations.B: SAW's deep penetration capability allows narrower groove angles (30-45° included angle) than most other processes, reducing filler metal requirements and distortion while still achieving complete joint fusion.
explanations.C: 60-70° is typical for SMAW but unnecessarily wide for SAW's penetration capability.
explanations.D: 90° or greater is excessive and wastes filler metal; SAW's deep penetration allows narrower, more efficient grooves.

questions.taskTitle: Welds using submerged arc welding (SAW) process
questions.subtask: D-15.04 Performs weld using SAW equipment
questions.question: When performing SAW and excessive spatter occurs, what is the most likely cause?

options.A: Proper parameters with adequate flux coverage
options.B: Inadequate flux coverage exposing arc to atmosphere
options.C: Travel speed too slow
options.D: Electrode extension too long

explanations.A: Proper parameters and flux coverage produce minimal spatter; this describes correct operation.
explanations.B: Excessive SAW spatter indicates inadequate flux depth or coverage allowing arc exposure to atmosphere; the flux blanket must completely submerge the arc to eliminate spatter.
explanations.C: Slow travel speed may affect bead shape but doesn't typically cause spatter when flux coverage is adequate.
explanations.D: Electrode extension affects resistive heating but isn't the primary spatter cause when flux coverage is proper.

questions.taskTitle: Welds using submerged arc welding (SAW) process
questions.subtask: D-15.04 Performs weld using SAW equipment
questions.question: For SAW welding on contaminated steel surfaces, what pre-weld preparation is most critical?

options.A: No preparation needed; SAW burns through all contamination
options.B: Thorough cleaning to remove rust, scale, oil, paint, and moisture
options.C: Apply additional flux to compensate for contamination
options.D: Increase current to maximum to burn off contamination

explanations.A: SAW does not effectively burn through contamination; porosity and defects result from welding contaminated surfaces.
explanations.B: SAW requires clean surfaces free of rust, scale, oil, paint, and moisture to prevent porosity, slag inclusions, and lack of fusion; the flux system cannot compensate for base metal contamination.
explanations.C: Additional flux doesn't remove base metal contaminants that cause porosity and fusion problems.
explanations.D: Higher current doesn't eliminate contamination effects and may worsen problems through increased gas evolution.

questions.taskTitle: Welds using submerged arc welding (SAW) process
questions.subtask: D-15.04 Performs weld using SAW equipment
questions.question: When performing SAW on stainless steel, what difference from carbon steel welding is most important?

options.A: No differences; parameters are identical
options.B: Use stainless-specific flux formulated for proper chemistry and slag removal
options.C: Much higher current required than carbon steel
options.D: Flux is not needed for stainless steel SAW

explanations.A: Stainless steel requires specifically formulated flux; carbon steel flux is not appropriate.
explanations.B: Stainless steel SAW requires specially formulated flux that maintains alloy chemistry (chromium and nickel), prevents oxidation, provides proper slag characteristics, and ensures corrosion resistance in the weld metal.
explanations.C: Current levels for stainless are often similar to or slightly lower than carbon steel, not much higher.
explanations.D: Flux is essential for all SAW applications including stainless steel for shielding and slag formation.

questions.taskTitle: Welds using submerged arc welding (SAW) process
questions.subtask: D-15.04 Performs weld using SAW equipment
questions.question: For SAW on thick sections requiring multiple passes, what is the recommended bead sequence?

options.A: Random bead placement throughout the joint
options.B: Complete one side fully before starting the opposite side
options.C: Alternating or balanced sequence to control distortion and residual stress
options.D: Fill from top to bottom only

explanations.A: Random placement creates unpredictable stress patterns and doesn't follow quality welding practice.
explanations.B: Completing one side creates severe imbalanced heating and distortion.
explanations.C: Multi-pass SAW should use alternating or balanced sequence (such as backstep technique or balanced fill) to minimize distortion and manage residual stresses, similar principles to other welding processes but adapted for SAW's high heat input.
explanations.D: Simple top-to-bottom fill may not optimize stress distribution; balanced sequencing is preferred.

questions.taskTitle: Welds using submerged arc welding (SAW) process
questions.subtask: D-15.04 Performs weld using SAW equipment
questions.question: When performing SAW with automatic voltage control (AVC), what does the system maintain?

options.A: Constant amperage regardless of arc length changes
options.B: Constant arc length by adjusting electrode height as needed
options.C: Maximum possible travel speed
options.D: Flux temperature

explanations.A: Constant voltage power sources maintain voltage, not amperage; AVC maintains arc length.
explanations.B: Automatic Voltage Control (AVC) monitors arc voltage and adjusts electrode height (up or down) to maintain constant arc length despite workpiece variations, ensuring consistent penetration and bead quality.
explanations.C: Travel speed is set separately; AVC controls arc length via electrode height adjustment.
explanations.D: AVC controls arc length through electrode positioning, not flux temperature.

questions.taskTitle: Welds using submerged arc welding (SAW) process
questions.subtask: D-15.04 Performs weld using SAW equipment
questions.question: For SAW fillet welding, what leg size ratio (vertical to horizontal) indicates proper heat distribution?

options.A: Vertical leg much larger than horizontal leg
options.B: Horizontal leg much larger than vertical leg
options.C: Approximately equal leg sizes (1:1 ratio for equal member thickness)
options.D: Leg size ratio is not important

explanations.A: Unequal legs with vertical larger indicates improper heat distribution toward vertical member.
explanations.B: Larger horizontal leg indicates heat favoritism toward horizontal member.
explanations.C: Proper SAW fillet welding with equal member thickness produces approximately equal leg sizes (1:1 ratio), indicating balanced heat distribution and complete fusion to both members.
explanations.D: Leg size ratio is critical quality indicator revealing heat distribution and potential lack of fusion issues.

questions.taskTitle: Welds using submerged arc welding (SAW) process
questions.subtask: D-15.04 Performs weld using SAW equipment
questions.question: When using SAW strip cladding for corrosion-resistant overlay, what electrode configuration provides the best results?

options.A: Single solid wire electrode
options.B: Flat strip electrode (typically 30-90 mm wide)
options.C: Multiple small diameter wires in parallel
options.D: Tubular flux-cored electrode

explanations.A: Single solid wire is used for standard SAW but not optimal for wide cladding coverage.
explanations.B: SAW strip cladding uses flat consumable strip electrode (typically 30-90 mm wide, 0.5 mm thick) providing wide coverage with minimal dilution, ideal for applying corrosion-resistant overlay efficiently.
explanations.C: Multiple wires can be used but strip electrode provides wider, more uniform coverage for cladding.
explanations.D: Tubular electrodes are not standard for SAW; solid wire or strip are typical consumables.

questions.taskTitle: Welds using submerged arc welding (SAW) process
questions.subtask: D-15.04 Performs weld using SAW equipment
questions.question: For SAW welding, what safety consideration is unique compared to visible arc processes?

options.A: No arc flash hazard exists because arc is submerged
options.B: UV radiation can still escape from flux blanket gaps requiring face protection
options.C: No PPE is required for SAW operators
options.D: SAW produces no fumes or gases

explanations.A: While reduced, arc flash hazard still exists if flux coverage is inadequate or gaps occur.
explanations.B: Even though the arc is submerged, UV radiation can escape through gaps in flux coverage or around the electrode entry point; face shields and protective clothing remain necessary for SAW operations.
explanations.C: Full PPE is required for SAW including face protection, protective clothing, gloves, and safety footwear.
explanations.D: SAW produces fumes from flux and base metal requiring adequate ventilation like all welding processes.

questions.taskTitle: Welds using submerged arc welding (SAW) process
questions.subtask: D-15.04 Performs weld using SAW equipment
questions.question: When performing SAW root pass on open-root groove welds, what backside indication confirms adequate penetration?

options.A: No backside indication is visible during welding
options.B: Small uniform bead visible on backside after slag removal
options.C: Complete burn-through creating large hole
options.D: Heavy slag buildup on backside

explanations.A: Backside indication is checked after welding, not during; SAW arc is not visible during operation.
explanations.B: Proper SAW root pass on open-root joints produces small, uniform backside bead (reinforcement) visible after slag removal, confirming complete penetration without excessive drop-through or burn-through.
explanations.C: Complete burn-through with large hole indicates excessive heat input or improper parameters causing defects.
explanations.D: Slag on backside suggests flux feeding through the joint; proper technique keeps flux on top side.

questions.taskTitle: Welds using submerged arc welding (SAW) process
questions.subtask: D-15.04 Performs weld using SAW equipment
questions.question: For SAW welding requiring low hydrogen levels, what maximum moisture content in flux is typically acceptable?

options.A: 10% moisture by weight
options.B: 5% moisture by weight
options.C: Less than 0.1% (essentially dry)
options.D: Moisture content is not critical for SAW

explanations.A: 10% moisture would introduce massive hydrogen levels causing severe cracking problems.
explanations.B: 5% moisture is far too high for low-hydrogen requirements in crack-sensitive applications.
explanations.C: Low-hydrogen SAW applications require essentially dry flux (typically <0.1% moisture content), achieved through proper baking and storage in heated hoppers, preventing hydrogen-induced cracking.
explanations.D: Moisture content is critical; damp flux introduces hydrogen causing cracking in restrained joints on high-strength steels.

questions.taskTitle: Welds using submerged arc welding (SAW) process
questions.subtask: D-15.04 Performs weld using SAW equipment
questions.question: When performing SAW on weathering steel, what post-weld consideration ensures uniform weathering appearance?

options.A: Paint the weld immediately after cooling
options.B: Use matching weathering steel composition flux-wire system allowing weld to weather similarly to base metal
options.C: Coat weld with oil to prevent any weathering
options.D: Grind weld flush and apply patina coating

explanations.A: Painting defeats the purpose of weathering steel's protective oxide formation.
explanations.B: Weathering steel SAW requires flux-wire system matching base metal alloy content (Cu, Cr, Ni, P) so weld metal develops similar protective patina, ensuring uniform appearance and corrosion resistance.
explanations.C: Oil prevents weathering; the intent is to allow matching weathering behavior.
explanations.D: While surface finish may be addressed, chemical matching of weld to base metal is fundamental.

questions.taskTitle: Welds using submerged arc welding (SAW) process
questions.subtask: D-15.04 Performs weld using SAW equipment
questions.question: For SAW on galvanized steel, what modification helps manage zinc vaporization?

options.A: No modification needed; weld directly over galvanizing
options.B: Remove galvanizing from weld area or use increased voltage with adequate ventilation
options.C: Use maximum current to burn off zinc instantly
options.D: Apply additional flux to trap zinc vapors

explanations.A: Welding directly over heavy galvanizing causes porosity from zinc vaporization.
explanations.B: SAW on galvanized steel works best with galvanizing removed from weld area, or if welding over coating, use slightly higher voltage promoting zinc burnoff ahead of puddle with adequate ventilation for zinc fumes.
explanations.C: Maximum current doesn't prevent zinc-induced porosity; voltage adjustment and ventilation are key.
explanations.D: Additional flux doesn't prevent zinc from vaporizing into weld metal causing porosity.

questions.taskTitle: Welds using submerged arc welding (SAW) process
questions.subtask: D-15.04 Performs weld using SAW equipment
questions.question: When performing SAW and arc blow occurs despite using AC current, what additional measure can help?

options.A: Reduce work clamp size
options.B: Position work clamp strategically or use multiple clamps to balance magnetic fields
options.C: Increase voltage dramatically
options.D: Remove all flux from the area

explanations.A: Reducing clamp size worsens electrical contact and doesn't address residual magnetic field issues.
explanations.B: Even with AC current (which largely eliminates arc blow), residual magnetism or clamp positioning can cause issues; strategic work clamp placement or using multiple clamps to balance fields can help minimize remaining arc deflection.
explanations.C: Voltage changes don't address the magnetic forces causing arc blow.
explanations.D: Removing flux eliminates SAW shielding and doesn't solve magnetic arc blow issues.

questions.taskTitle: Welds using submerged arc welding (SAW) process
questions.subtask: D-15.04 Performs weld using SAW equipment
questions.question: For SAW welds requiring post-weld heat treatment (PWHT), what consideration affects flux selection?

options.A: Flux selection is unrelated to PWHT requirements
options.B: Flux-wire system must provide chemistry and mechanical properties that maintain requirements after PWHT
options.C: Any flux works if PWHT temperature is below 200°C
options.D: PWHT eliminates all flux effects on properties

explanations.A: Flux selection critically affects as-welded and post-PWHT properties.
explanations.B: When PWHT is specified, the SAW flux-wire system must be selected to provide weld metal chemistry and resulting properties (strength, toughness) that meet requirements both as-welded and after the specified PWHT cycle.
explanations.C: PWHT is typically 550-650°C for pressure vessel steel; 200°C is too low and flux choice remains critical.
explanations.D: PWHT modifies but doesn't eliminate the effects of flux chemistry on final weld metal properties.

questions.taskTitle: Welds using submerged arc welding (SAW) process
questions.subtask: D-15.04 Performs weld using SAW equipment
questions.question: When using SAW for hard-facing applications, what technique minimizes base metal dilution?

options.A: Use maximum current for deep penetration
options.B: Use lower current with higher travel speed and proper flux selection
options.C: Eliminate flux entirely for hard-facing
options.D: Use multiple passes at maximum heat input

explanations.A: Maximum current increases penetration and dilution, reducing hardfacing alloy concentration in deposit.
explanations.B: SAW hardfacing uses controlled parameters (lower current, appropriate travel speed) with flux formulated for hardfacing to minimize base metal dilution, maintaining hardness and wear resistance in the deposited layer.
explanations.C: Flux is still required in SAW for shielding; special hardfacing fluxes are formulated for these applications.
explanations.D: Maximum heat input increases dilution; controlled heat input with possible multiple layers maintains hardness.

questions.taskTitle: Welds using submerged arc welding (SAW) process
questions.subtask: D-15.04 Performs weld using SAW equipment
questions.question: For SAW narrow-gap welding with oscillation, what oscillation width is typically appropriate?

options.A: Oscillation width equal to groove width
options.B: Oscillation width slightly less than groove width ensuring sidewall contact
options.C: Oscillation width twice the groove width
options.D: No oscillation used in narrow-gap SAW

explanations.A: Equal width risks inadequate sidewall fusion if electrode doesn't dwell at extremes.
explanations.B: Narrow-gap SAW oscillation width should be slightly less than groove width (typically 1-2mm less), ensuring electrode reaches sidewalls for fusion while avoiding binding or touching walls.
explanations.C: Twice groove width is impossible in a narrow gap and would cause electrode interference.
explanations.D: Oscillation is essential in narrow-gap SAW to ensure adequate sidewall fusion throughout the depth.

questions.taskTitle: Welds using submerged arc welding (SAW) process
questions.subtask: D-15.04 Performs weld using SAW equipment
questions.question: When performing SAW and poor slag removal is experienced, what is the most likely cause?

options.A: Proper parameters producing optimal slag
options.B: Voltage too low creating glassy, tightly adhering slag
options.C: Base metal too clean
options.D: Excessive flux depth

explanations.A: Good parameters produce easily removable slag; poor removal indicates a problem.
explanations.B: Voltage too low in SAW creates glassy, tightly adhering slag difficult to remove; increasing voltage slightly promotes proper slag characteristics allowing easier detachment from the weld bead.
explanations.C: Clean base metal is desirable and doesn't cause poor slag removal; parameter or flux issues are typical causes.
explanations.D: Flux depth affects arc shielding, not slag removal characteristics which depend on parameters and flux type.

questions.taskTitle: Welds using submerged arc welding (SAW) process
questions.subtask: D-15.04 Performs weld using SAW equipment
questions.question: For SAW production welding requiring consistent quality, what quality control measure is most important?

options.A: Visual inspection only after all welding is complete
options.B: Regular monitoring of parameters, flux condition, and systematic testing per welding procedure
options.C: Random parameter changes to test different conditions
options.D: No quality control needed for automated SAW

explanations.A: Waiting until completion to inspect risks producing many defective welds before discovery.
explanations.B: SAW quality control requires regular parameter monitoring, flux condition verification (dryness, contamination), systematic destructive and NDT testing per procedures, and documentation ensuring consistent production quality.
explanations.C: Random changes introduce variables compromising quality; consistent parameters per qualified procedures are required.
explanations.D: Even automated SAW requires quality control monitoring; automation doesn't eliminate need for verification and testing.
